The king asked: Is it good for a person to experience pleasure or not? Is it good for a person to experience suffering
or not?
Is it not good?
Did the Buddha not say that there is pleasure or suffering?
The king said:
If there is no suffering, it is as if there is no existence.
Nagasena asked the king:
If one burns iron and puts it in one's hand, would it not burn one's hand?
If one takes ice and puts it in one's hand, would the ice burn one's hand?
The king said:
Yes.
Both hands are affected.
Nagasena asked the king:
Are the objects in both hands hot?
The king said:
Not both are hot.
Nagasena said:
Are both cold?
The king said:
Not both are cold.ğŸ”½Nagasena said:
Yes.
Both hands are burned.
NÄgasena said:
I ask the king a question. When the king's hands are hot, are they both hot?
If they are both cold, are they both cold?
Why can a cold and a hot hand be said to burn a person's hand together?
The king said:
My wisdom is very shallow and cannot reach this difficulty.
I wish NÄgasena would explain it for me.
NÄgasena said:

The Buddha's scriptures say that there are six things that make people happy inside, six things that make people sad inside, and six things that make people neither happy nor sad, and there are also six things that make people sad outside.
The king asked:
What are the six things that make people happy inside?
NÄgasena said:
First, the eyes see something and have expectations, so it makes people happy inside;
Second, the ears hear good sounds and have expectations, so it makes people happy inside;
Third, the nose smells good fragrance and hopes for more, thus causing inner joy;
Fourth, the tongue tastes delicious flavors and hopes for more, thus causing inner joy;
Fifth, the body experiences smoothness and hopes for more, thus causing inner joy;
Sixth, the mind experiences pleasant feelings and hopes for more, thus causing inner joy.
In this way, these six things cause inner joy.
The king asked again:
What are the six external things that cause joy?
NÄgasena said:

First, the eyes see good forms but cannot always obtain them. They should all be abandoned. Then, one contemplates that they are impermanent. This causes external joy;ğŸ”½Second, the ears hear good sounds but cannot always obtain them. They should all be abandoned. This causes external joy;
Third, the nose smells good fragrances but cannot always obtain them. They should all be abandoned. This causes external joy;
Fourth, if one obtains delicious food with the mouth, thinking of it as something that cannot always be obtained, one should abandon it, and therefore it makes people happy outside;
Fifth, if one's body obtains softness and smoothness, thinking of it as something that cannot always be obtained, one should abandon it, and therefore it makes people happy outside;

Sixth, if one's mind thinks of and contemplates desires, thinking of them as all impermanent and to be abandoned, thinking of them as later to be enjoyed again, this makes people happy outside. These are the six things that make people happy outside.
The king asked again:
What are the six internal things that make people sad inside?
NÄgasena said:
First, what makes people sad inside is that the eyes see what is unpleasant, making people sad inside;
Second, the ears hear what is not wanted to be heard, making people sad inside;
Third, the nose smells what is not wanted to be smelled, making people sad inside;
Fourth, the mouth obtains what is not wanted to be obtained, making people sad inside;
Fifth, the body does not desire to be attached to something, but is attached to it, causing inner sorrow;
Sixth, the mind cannot bear to be happy with something, but has it, causing inner sorrow.
These are the six things that cause inner sorrow for a person.
The king asked again:
What are the six external things that cause people to be unhappy?
NÄgasena said:
First, seeing evil forms with the eyes causes people to be unhappy;
Second, hearing evil sounds with the ears causes people to be unhappy;
Third, smelling foul odors with the nose causes people to be unhappy;
Fourth, experiencing bitter flavors with the tongue causes people to be unhappy;
Fifth, the body wearing rough and tough clothes causes people to be unhappy;
Sixth, the mind having what it detests causes people to be unhappy.
These are the six external things that cause people to be unhappy.
The king asked again:
What are the six things that cause people to neither sorrow nor rejoice?
NÄgasena said:
First, seeing something with the eyes neither causes joy nor sorrow;
Second, the ears hear sounds and are neither delighted nor sorrowful;
Third, the nose smells scents and is neither delighted nor sorrowful;
Fourth, the mouth obtains flavors and is neither delighted nor sorrowful;
Fifth, the body experiences touch and is neither delighted nor sorrowful;
Sixth, the mind thinks thoughts and is neither delighted nor sorrowful.
These are the six internal matters that cause people to neither delight nor sorrow.
The king asked again:
What are the six external matters that cause people to sorrow?
NÄgasena said:
First, when the eyes see a dead person, they think to themselves that the body and all things are impermanent. The person thinks to themselves:
'I have this thought, why haven't I attained the Way?'
This causes external sorrow.
Second, the ears do not enjoy good sounds. The person thinks to themselves:
'I have this thought, why haven't I attained the Way?'
This causes external sorrow.
Third, the nose does not enjoy fragrant scents. The person thinks to themselves:
I have this thought, why can't I attain the Way?
Because of external worries.
Fourth, the mouth does not taste bitterness or sweetness. The person thinks to themselves:
I have this thought, why can't I attain it?
Because of external worries.
Fifth, the body does not like smoothness and cannot endure roughness. The person thinks to themselves:
I have this thought, why can't I attain the Way?
Because of external worries.
Sixth, the mind does not delight in desire. The person thinks to themselves:
I have this thought, why can't I attain the Way?
Because of external worries.
These are the six things that cause people to worry externally.
The king said:
Excellent, excellent!
The king asked Ä€nanda again:
After a person dies, who is reborn in the next life?
Ä€nanda said:
The name and body are reborn in the next life.
The king asked Ä€nanda:
Does the name and body of the deceased person continue to be reborn?ğŸ”½Ä€nanda said:
Yes.
No, it is not.
The name is not intentional, nor is the body. It is this name and body that create good and evil in this world and give rise to them in the next world.
The king said:

If in this world one uses this name and body to create good and evil, and the body is not reborn in the next world, then one can create good and evil to the utmost, and can be liberated directly, and will not undergo further suffering, right?
NÄgasena said:
If one creates good and evil in this world and is not reborn in the next world, then one can be liberated, right?
People create good and evil without stopping, and are born again later, and therefore cannot be liberated.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a person who steals someone else's fruits and vegetables. The owner catches the fruit thief and brings him before the king, saying:
'This person stole my fruits.'
The thief says:
'I did not steal this person's fruits. These are small saplings that he planted. He did not originally plant fruits.'
I myself picked the fruit. Why would I steal it?
I did not steal this person's fruit. I should not be guilty.
NÄgasena asked the king:
In this case, which of the two is right and which is wrong?
The king said:
The planter is right, as he originally planted the crop.
The thief is at fault and should be guilty.
NÄgasena said:
Why is stealing considered a crime?
The king said:
The reason stealing is a crime is because the crop was originally planted by the planter, and the fruit grows from the roots of the planting.
NÄgasena said:
The birth of a person is also like this. In this life, using this physical body to do good or evil, one is reborn in the next life. The good and evil done in this life is the root.
NÄgasena said:
For example, if a person steals another person's grain, and the owner catches the thief and asks him:
'Why did you steal my rice?'
The thief said:
'I did not steal your rice.
You planted the rice, and I took the rice.
Why should I be guilty of theft?'
The two men pulled each other to the king's presence and said this, who is right and who is wrong?
The king said:
Planting rice and grain is right, stealing is wrong.
NÄgasena said:
How do you know that stealing rice is wrong?
The king said:
The one who plants rice has it, the one who does not plant rice does not have it. Why would there be rice?
NÄgasena said:
The birth of a person is also like this. In this life, using this name and form, one does good or evil, and then is born in the next life.
Doing good or evil in this life is the basis.
NÄgasena said:
For example, a person in the cold of winter wants to warm themselves by lighting a fire in a house.
The person abandoned the fire and left, and it gradually burned the wall and soil, burning the house and connecting to the building.
The owner of the house said, The person who started the fire should be brought before the king and told:
'This person started a fire that spread and burned my building.'
The person who started the fire said:
'I started a small fire to warm myself, I did not burn the building.'
NÄgasena asked the king:
Who is at fault?
The king said:
The person who started the fire is at fault, it is his fault.
NÄgasena said:
Human birth is also like this.
For example, a person uses this name in this world to do good and evil, and then is born in the next world.
The good and evil done in this world is the root.
NÄgasena said:
For example, a person lights a candle at night and places it against a wall to illuminate themselves while eating.
The candle gradually moves and touches the wall, bamboo, and wooden materials, and then burns a house.
The fire grew and spread, burning an entire city.
The people of the city all gathered and said:
Why did you burn an entire city like this?
The one who started the fire said:
I just lit a small candle to illuminate my meal.
This is a big fire, not my fire.
Thus they argued and dragged each other to the king.
NÄgasena asked the king:
Who is right and who is wrong in this case?
The king said:
The one who started the fire is wrong.
NÄgasena said:
How do you know?
The king said:
It originated from fire.
After your meal, you should extinguish the fire, but you let the fire burn an entire city.
NÄgasena said:
Human life is also like this.
In this life, one creates good and evil with this physical body, and then is reborn in the next life.
The good and evil deeds done in this world are the basis.
People do not know how to do good and evil, so they cannot attain liberation.
NÄsa said:
It is like a man who uses money to marry a young girl from another family.
Later, when the girl grows up, another man comes to marry her and takes her as his wife.
The family that was previously engaged says:
'Why did you take back the wife you gave away?'
The later family says:
'You yourself married the girl when she was young, and I myself married the wife when I was older. Why do you want to take back the wife you gave away?'
They then pull each other before the king.
NÄsa said:
Your Majesty!
Who is right and who is wrong in this case?
The king said:
The previously engaged family is right.
NÄsa said:
Your Majesty, how do you know?
The king said:ğŸ”½The previously engaged family is right.
This girl was small before, but now she is gradually growing up, so we know it is the same. She is the daughter-in-law of the previous betrothal.
Nagasena said:
The birth of a person is also like this.
In this life, using this name and form, one creates good and evil karma, and is reborn in the next life.
The good and evil created in this life is the root.
Nagasena said:
It is like a person who takes a jar and buys milk from a cowherd's house. After obtaining the milk, he entrusts it to the owner, saying:
'I will be back soon.'
That person comes back in a moment and takes the jar of milk, which has turned into yogurt.
The milk buyer says:
'I entrusted the milk to you, but now you are giving me yogurt in return.
' The cowherd says:
'This is your own milk, which has now turned into yogurt.'

Nagasena asked the king:
Who is the honest one in this case?
The king said:
The cowherd is the honest one.
NÄgasena said:
Why do you know this?
The king said:
You yourself bought the milk and left it on the ground, and it naturally turned into curd.
What fault does the cowherd have?
NÄgasena said:
The birth of a person is also like this.
In this life, a person uses this body to do good and evil, and then is reborn in the next life.
The good and evil done in this life are the basis.
The king asked again:
Will NÄgasena be reborn in the next life?
NÄgasena replied to the king:
Why ask this?
I have already said before that if I have affection and love, I will be reborn in the next life;
if I have no affection and love, I will not be reborn.
NÄgasena said:
It is like a person who exhausts his strength serving the king. The king should know his goodness and bestow wealth upon him.
When that person obtains the wealth, he uses it to the fullest extent, wearing clothes and eating food, enjoying himself with pleasure.
That person argues and says:
'I have made a contribution to the king, but the king has never rewarded me.'
NÄgasena asked the king:
It is like that person who obtains a reward but says he has never received one.
Can his words be used?
The king said:
His words cannot be used.
NÄgasena said:
Therefore, I tell the king, if I have affection and love, I will be reborn in the next world; if I have no affection and love, I will not be reborn in the next world.
The king said:
Excellent, excellent!
The king asked NÄgasena:
What you said earlier about the name and body of a person, what is the name and what is the body?
NÄsa said:
The present body is the form, and what the mind thinks is the name.
The king asked again:
Why does a person's name go to the next life and be reborn, while the body does not go to be reborn?
NÄsa said:
A person's body is connected by the name before and after.
It is like an egg, which is formed by the liquid inside and the skin on the outside.
A person's name is connected to the body, and it is not separate like this.
The king said:
Excellent!
The king asked NÄsa again:
What is long?
NÄsa said:
Past events are long, and future events are also long;
Present events have no length.
The king said:
Excellent!
The king asked NÄsa again:
Is there really length?
NÄsa said:
There is length, and there is no length.
The king said again:
What is meant by 'having a long time'?
What is meant by 'having no long time'?
NÄgasena said:
Those who have attained the path and nirvÄá¹‡a have no long time, those who have not yet attained the path and will have to die and be reborn again have a long time.
If a person is generous and filial to their parents in this world, they will obtain blessings in the future.
The king said:
Excellent! Excellent!
The king asked NÄgasena again:
As for the past, the future, and the present, which of these three is the basis?
NÄgasena said:
The past, the future, and the present are all based on ignorance.

When ignorance arises, the spirit arises. When the spirit arises, the body arises. When the body arises, the name arises. When the name arises, form arises. When form arises, the six knowledges arise. The first is eye knowledge, the second is ear knowledge, the third is nose knowledge, the fourth is mouth knowledge, the fifth is body knowledge, and the sixth is mind knowledge. These are the six knowledges. These six things all face outward.
What are they that face outward?
The eye faces form, the ear faces sound, the nose faces smell, the mouth faces taste, the body faces smoothness, and the mind faces greed. These are the six outwards.
